thread.title: Data retention law fatal to rural ISPs
thread.title_full: Data retention law fatal to rural ISPs | Business Spectator

author: Mitchell Bingemann
title: Data retention law fatal to rural ISPs
text:
The government’s plan to implement its data retention regime is placing small-scale internet providers at risk of collapse as they struggle with the costs and time needed to comply with the new scheme.
The metadata laws require all telecoms companies to store their customers’ telephone and internet records for a minimum of two years.
The scheme also forces telcos to retain metadata about their customers, including the time, identity, billing information, general locations and IP addresses of the senders and recipients — but not the content of communications.
But fewer than one in five telcos say they are ready to store all the information required under the new data retention laws — which officially came into force on October 13.
Smaller service providers from rural and regional Australia have warned of massive damage to their businesses if they are forced to comply with the controversial law.
“This is over-regulation, plain and simple. The cost of implementing this scheme would be completely disproportionate to any benefit it delivers,” Ross Wheeler, the owner of Albury Local internet, told The Australian.
“In over 20 years we have never had that sort of request for information on our customers from a law enforcement agency. So the cost for implementing this stuff, for what will be a minuscule possibility, is completely disproportionate.”
Albury Local internet has been in operation for more than 20 years, servicing the southern NSW town’s internet needs.
But Mr Wheeler said if the scheme went ahead without proper government assistance, his business would be irrevocably damaged.
Albury Local internet submitted its so-called Data Retention Implementation Plan to the Attorney-General’s office in May. The telco asked for a number of exemptions — including one that would excuse it from the costly process of encrypting all of its data — but so far its requests have been rejected by the Attorney General’s department.
Installing the IT systems and complying with the scheme would cost Albury Local internet more than $100,000 to implement and at least $10,000 a year in operating costs.
Mr Wheeler said the costliest components of the scheme were the requirements to encrypt data and store it for two years. The company currently holds on to customer data for just 10 days.
“I can stretch it a little bit but not to two damn years,” Mr Wheeler said. “This hugely increases the compliance costs. And if I had to reach into my pocket, I’m out, game over, end of story.”
Another owner of a small, Sydney-based ISP — who asked to remain anonymous — said it too would go out of business unless the Attorney-General granted exemptions to the scheme.
“We are profitable, but if we were to implement this without funding then it would basically send us bust,” they said. “We have stopped signing contracts with new providers and have moved to outsourcing so we don’t have to comply with all these onerous conditions. The AGD think they are being helpful, but they aren’t doing enough. They need to change it so it can work with smaller telcos.”
The government has pledged $131 million to subsidise the cost of the data retention scheme for telcos. While the allocation of the $131m kitty has not been finalised, the Attorney-General’s department plans to prioritise funding to smaller ISPs.
